info.game_comments:
2002 College Championship final game 2.
From the Schottenstein Center at the Ohio State University in Columbus.

(1, 1).clue: This Civil War general who remarked that "War is hell" made life hell for Georgia during his march to the sea

(2, 1).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew reports from Paris)  A military parade goes down the Champs-Elysees from the Arc de Triomphe on this day, which the French call National Day

(3, 1).clue: Both Shakespeare & Clement Clarke Moore wrote about this creature not "stirring"

(4, 1).clue: Played by Julie Benz, Darla was the vampire who turned this David Boreanaz character into a vampire as well

(5, 1).clue: That kid in the Mazda commercials could tell you the lens Roger Cuvillier developed in 1949 could do this

(6, 1).clue: In Exodus 5:1 he demands, "Let my people go"

(1, 2).clue: He was the first Army general to become president of the United States

(2, 2).clue: The first large balloon to float along in this fall event was Felix the Cat in 1927

(3, 2).clue: "I never saw a purple" one of these: "I never hope to see one, but I can tell you anyhow, I'd rather see than be one"

(4, 2).clue: "Hail to the Chief", & to this series, seen here

(5, 2).clue: A primitive 3-D color version of this was demonstrated by John Logie Baird in 1941

(6, 2).clue: God warned him to get ready, which this man did, even though he was 600 years old when the flood finally came

(1, 3).clue: A onetime brigadier general, he'd been reduced to lt. colonel when he died at Little Bighorn in 1876

(2, 3).clue: Every March 2 this state commemorates the 1836 signing of a Declaration of Independence from Mexico

(3, 3).clue: "All right", said this animal: "and this time it vanished quite slowly, beginning with the end of the tail"

(4, 3).clue: In the "Eww!" department, stunts on this NBC show have included bobbing in worms & eating cockroaches

(5, 3).clue: In the 1940s Willem Kolff built a machine that could clean your blood if these failed

(6, 3).clue: In the first book of Samuel, David defeats this Philistine by hitting him with a rock

(1, 4).clue: General Stonewall Jackson graduated from this military academy in 1846

(2, 4).clue: Hold your nose & run to this Vermont capital for the International Rotten Sneaker Contest

(3, 4).clue: Groucho Marx said, "One morning I shot" this "in my pajamas.  How he got into my pajamas I'll never know"

(4, 4).clue: On my honor, David James Elliott plays Navy cmdr. & lawyer Harm Rabb, Jr. on this series

(5, 4).clue: The first food sold in one of these containers came out in 1947 & was whipped cream

(6, 4).clue: In the Old Testament, God allows Satan to afflict this man in order to test his faith

(1, 5).clue: Seen here, this general gained fame fighting in WW1, WW2 & the Korean War

(2, 5).clue: In August 2002 Los Angeles celebrated the seventh annual festival of this, another name for soybean curd

(3, 5).clue: William Blake wrote that "The pride of" this bird "is the glory of God"

(4, 5).clue: Rory attends the prestigious Chilton Prep School on this WB series

(5, 5).clue: Adeline Gray in June 1942 made the first jump in a parachute made out of this material

(6, 5).clue: In 1 Kings 3, he wisely suggests cutting a child in two in order to reveal its true mother

(1, 1).clue: He discovered that heating wine killed the microbes that make it turn sour

(2, 1).clue: Officials at drug maker Imclone had a sudden urge to sell company stock after bad news from this government body

(3, 1).clue: Tinker Bell's out of the drawer -- goes behind the clock -- looks like she's going to pull Wendy's hair

(5, 1).clue: In 1795 in Chapel Hill the university of this state became the first U.S. state university to open its doors

(6, 1).clue: This term for a film's total box office take comes from the Old French for "large"

(1, 2).clue: (Sofia of the Clue Crew reports from the Field Museum in Chicago.)  Sue the T. rex was found to possess this bone, which further links birds & dinosaurs--which half do you want?

(2, 2).clue: In the 1990s McDonald's infiltrated & spied on this "colorful" environmental group

(3, 2).clue: Interesting coaching move by Malcolm, using branches from Birnam Wood to disguise his army

(5, 2).clue: (Bill Clinton gives the clue)  Before I became a Rhodes Scholar, I earned my bachelor's degree in international affairs from this univ. in our nation's capital

(6, 2).clue: As the name suggests, these previews of future attractions were originally shown after the main feature

(1, 3).clue: The first white dwarf star to be discovered was a companion to this dog star

(2, 3).clue: This accounting firm shredded too exuberantly & was convicted of obstructing justice in 2002

(3, 3).clue: Jim & Laura keep dancing -- they hit the table & it looks -- yep, the little unicorn is broken, you could see that coming

(4, 3).clue: It could have been called Engelsism(7)

(5, 3).clue: This Jesuit university in downtown Milwaukee "Encourages students...to find God in all things"

(6, 3).clue: (Sarah & Cheryl of the Clue Crew give the clue together)  A certain rapid camera movement is called the swish type of this

(1, 4).clue: The remains of a 3.2 million-year-old hominid, discovered in 1974, were nicknamed this, after a Beatles song

(2, 4).clue: In 2002 this communications company revised some recent earnings downward about $4 billion

(3, 4).clue: Tesman & Mrs. Elvsted are blathering on.  Not much action -- wait!  There's a gunshot!

(4, 4).clue: Preacher whom some witches didn't "Cotton" to(6)

(5, 4).clue: This university's original building, erected in Elko in 1874, became a hospital for indigents before it was leveled in 1920

(6, 4).clue: A TV image that retains big-screen proportions is called this, maybe because it's like looking through a mail slot

(1, 5).clue: In the 1770s Lavoisier discovered that air is made up mostly of oxygen & this gas

(2, 5).clue: In the 1890s the U.S. government went after a sugar-refining monopoly under this new law

(3, 5).clue: What's this?  I don't believe it!  Becket just said, "Unbar the door!"  He's letting in the knights!

(5, 5).clue: A Virginia university bears the name of this man who wrote the Virginia Declaration of Rights

(6, 5).clue: The art of creating movie sounds, like using cornstarch for snow under foot, is named for this man

(0, 0).clue: 1 of the 2 planets of the solar system not represented in Gustav Holst's 1916 work "The Planets"
